Given this reality, Defendant's request for qualified immunity would be best raised in a Motion for Summary Judgment after the close of discovery.  See DeMayo v. Nugent, 517 F.3d 11, 19 (1st Cir. 2008) ("If Nugent and Lugas wished to present evidence of additional facts that might refute or undermine DeMayo's pleadings, the place to do so was in their response to his motion.").

top_links.moving_heading: 2.  Plaintiff's First Amendment Claim.
top_links.moving_content: Officer Brandreth's actions in ticketing the Plaintiff under the state statute based on the specific facts which he observed meant that the statute was applied in a content neutral manner. There are no allegations in the Complaint that this action was taken because of the specific speech that Ms. Petrello was attempting to convey on the day in question (i.e., she had some sort of a poster with words written on it and there is no allegation that she was being sanctioned because of whatever the content was on that poster).  When a law restricts speech without regard to the type of message communicated, and only regulates the time, place or manner of speech, then the ordinance is what is called "content neutral."  Such a law has the virtue of not singling out any idea or topic for favored or unfavored treatment.  The government must only show that a restriction that is content neutral is narrowly tailored to serve significant governmental interests and that it would leave ample alternative channels for communication of the information. Cutting v. City of Portland, 802 F.3d 79, 84 (1st Cir. 2015). Ms. Petrello was not prohibited in any way from expressing herself adjacent to the sidewalk as much as she desired, and there is no allegation in the Complaint that there was any attempt to restrict this. Based on the allegations in the Complaint, it is undisputed that what was restricted by application of the statute, and under the specific factual circumstances of this case, was the Plaintiff's interaction with a several ton automobile which was traveling with a green light, which caused the vehicle to stop and thereby caused a traffic hazard. Enforcement of that statute under those specific facts was a reasonable time, place and manner restriction that did not violate the First Amendment.
top_links.response_heading: III. Count II - Violation of First Amendment Rights
top_links.response_content:
Defendant argues that it is not clearly established that a person has a First Amendment right to peacefully solicit motorists from a public place when this speech causes a motorist to slow down or stop in response to this speech.  See Def.'s Br. at 3.  Defendant is incorrect.   Though the "clearly established" inquiry does "not require a case directly on point," Glik, 655 F.3d at 84, basic First Amendment principles-along with case law from the United States Supreme Court, First Circuit, and other circuits-demonstrate the protected nature of Plaintiff's speech on June 3, 2015, regardless of the terms of the disorderly conduct statute.  See id. at 81 ("Basic First Amendment principles, along with case law from this and other circuits, answer that question unambiguously in the affirmative.").
As Plaintiff's Second Amended Complaint, the directive, and Defendant's own actions under the directive make clear, Defendant targeted Plaintiff's panhandling speech by criminalizing it solely based on the message it conveys and the motorist's response to it.  See Am. Compl. ¶35- 36., 40, 43, 70.  The directive, itself, focuses exclusively on panhandlers in a content-based fashion, therefore rendering it presumptively unconstitutional under the strict scrutiny analysis.  See, e.g., Thayer v. City of Worcester, 144 F. Supp. 3d 218, 233-34 (D. Mass. 2015) (ordinance targeting panhandling speech-namely, speech seeking an immediate donation of money or another thing of value-was content based and triggered strict scrutiny).  As is obvious from the facts alleged and the directive itself, if a motorist slows down to give a stranger a dollar unsolicited, the stranger would not be issued a summons because he is not a panhandler.  It was only when Plaintiff asked for a donation as a panhandler in a public place did Defendant elect to criminalize her speech after a motorist reacted to it.  Any officer should know that such targeting is improper under the First Amendment.
It is also clear that solicitation, panhandling, and begging are constitutionally-protected forms of speech. In Village of Schaumburg v. Citizens for a Better Environment, the United States Supreme Court struck down an ordinance that prohibited solicitation by certain organizations, holding that "charitable appeals for funds, on the street or door to door, involve a variety of speech interests-communication of information, the dissemination and propagation of views and ideas, and the advocacy of causes-that are within the protection of the First Amendment."  444 U.S. 620, 632 (1980).  As the Court explained, "solicitation is characteristically intertwined with informative and perhaps persuasive speech seeking support for particular causes or for particular views on economic, political, or social issues," and "without solicitation the flow of such information and advocacy would likely cease."  Id. at 620-21.
In the decades since Village of Schaumburg, courts have repeatedly reached the same result in the panhandling context.  The Second Circuit Court of Appeals has observed:
Begging frequently is accompanied by speech indicating the need for food, shelter, clothing, medical care or transportation.  Even without particularized speech, however, the presence of an unkempt and disheveled person holding out his or her hand or a cup to receive a donation itself conveys a message of need for support and assistance.
was impermissibly content-based).  Other courts, including those within the First Circuit, have agreed.  See, e.g., Clatterbuck v. City of Charlottesville, 708 F.3d 549, 556 (4th Cir. 2013) (plaintiff's complaint challenging no-solicitation zone survives motion to dismiss); Ayres v. City of Chicago, 125 F.3d 1010, 1015-16 (7th Cir. 1997) (granting injunction against ordinance forbidding the peddling of any merchandise, except newspapers, on either public property or certain private property in districts designated by the city council); Thayer, 144 F. Supp. 3d at 232 ("Soliciting contributions is expressive activity that is protected by the First Amendment."); McLaughlin v. City of Lowell, 140 F. Supp. 3d 177, 184 (D. Mass. 2015) ("Solicitations of money by organized charities are within the protection of the First Amendment.") (internal quotations omitted); Pindak v. Dart, 125 F. Supp. 3d 720, 766 (N.D. Ill. 2015) (rejecting qualified immunity, and explaining that "[t]he relevant case law clearly establishes Plaintiffs' First Amendment right to engage in ... panhandling"); Speet v. Schuette, 889 F. Supp. 2d 969, 978 (W.D. Mich. 2012) (holding unconstitutional Michigan statute prohibiting begging), aff'd, 726 F.3d 867 (6th Cir. 2013); Wilkinson v. State, 860 F. Supp. 2d 1284, 1288-90 (D. Utah 2012) (striking down statute stating that, in multiple circumstances, a person "may not sit, stand, or loiter on or near a roadway for the purpose of soliciting from the occupant of a vehicle"); Benefit v. City of Cambridge, 679 N.E.2d 184, 188 (Mass. 1997) (concluding that "there is no distinction of constitutional dimension between soliciting funds for oneself and for charities and therefore that peaceful begging constitutes communicative activity protected by the First Amendment").  In Benefit, for example, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court struck down a Massachusetts statute which made it a crime to beg without a license, finding that there was no compelling state interest justifying such a broad restriction on the right to freedom of speech:
The statute intrudes not only on the right of free communication, but it also implicates and suppresses an even broader right-the right to engage fellow human beings with the hope of receiving aid and compassion .... If such a basic transaction as peacefully requesting or giving casual help to the needy may be forbidden in all such places, then we may belong to the government that regulates us and not the other way around.
Benefit, 679 N.E.2d at 190 (emphasis added).
Plaintiff's speech is undoubtedly afforded First Amendment protection given that it occurred in a public place with no allegation that Plaintiff ever stepped in the roadway.  See McCullen v. Coakley, 134 S. Ct. 2518, 2529 (2014) ("It is no accident that public streets and sidewalks have developed as venues for the exchange of ideas.  Even today, they remain one of the few places where a speaker can be confident that he is not simply preaching to the choir.  With respect to other means of communication, an individual confronted with an uncomfortable message can always turn the page, change the channel, or leave the Web site.  Not so on public streets and sidewalks."); Doyle v. Comm'r, N.H. Dep't. of Resources & Economic Dev., 163 N.H. 215, 223 (2012) ("Traditional public forums are fundamental to the continuing vitality of our democracy, for time out of mind, [they] have been used for purposes of assembly, communicating thoughts between citizens, and discussing public questions.  As such, government entities are strictly limited in their ability to regulate private speech in [traditional public forums].") (internal quotations and citations omitted).
Speech directed at motorists from public places-like the speech engaged in by Plaintiff- is also constitutionally protected regardless of how motorists react to the speech.  This includes speech soliciting donations, as well as speech asking motorists to pull over, slow down, or honk. This clear principle was echoed in the recent First Circuit decision Cutting v. City of Portland, 802 F.3d 79 (1st Cir. 2015).  In that case, the First Circuit struck down a content-neutral ordinance that indiscriminately banned virtually all expressive activity in all of Portland's median strips.  This ordinance was motivated by a desire to restrict panhandling directed at motorists.  In rejecting the ordinance on First Amendment grounds, the First Circuit specifically explained how a median ban could impact protected panhandling speech, noting that one of the plaintiffs was a panhandler "who uses medians to panhandle" but who "finds sidewalks so useless for her purposes that she now takes a bus to a different town in order to panhandle from medians."  Id. at 89.  Here, the directive's content-based nature and lack of tailoring are patently obvious, and make this a much easier case than Cutting.  The directive upon which Defendant apparently relies focuses only on "panhandling"-namely, speech designed to solicit a donation.  See Def.'s Br. at 3.  And, as McCullen and Cutting make clear-cases in which content-neutral laws were struck down for lack of tailoring-a far more tailored approach here would be to address the motorist's conduct, not the speech of a speaker in a public place.4
Thus, by targeting only the pedestrian asking for money-rather than other pedestrians impacting motorists or drivers who are actually in the roadway-Defendant Officer Brandreth violated Plaintiff's clearly-established First Amendment rights, regardless of whether he was following Department policy or not.  It is axiomatic that a person's speech-including the speech of panhandlers-cannot be criminalized simply because of someone's reaction to it, even if that reaction is a motorist deciding to slow down in a roadway.  See, e.g., Comite de Jornaleros de Redondo Beach v. City of Redondo Beach, 657 F.3d 936 (9th Cir. 2011) (anti-solicitation ordinance that bars individuals from "stand[ing] on a street or highway and solicit[ing], or attempt[ing] to solicit, employment, business, or contributions from an occupant of any motor vehicle" is unconstitutional on its face); Valle Del Sol Inc. v. Whiting, 709 F.3d 808, 814 (9th Cir. 2013) (striking down law that made it unlawful for a motor vehicle occupant to hire or attempt to hire a person for work at another location from a stopped car that impeded traffic, or for a person to be hired in such a manner; while acknowledging "that Arizona has a real and substantial interest in traffic safety," holding that "Arizona, however, has failed to justify a need to serve that interest through targeting and penalizing day labor solicitation that blocks traffic, rather than directly targeting those who create traffic hazards without reference to their speech, as currently proscribed under the State's preexisting traffic laws") (emphasis added); Goedert v. City of Ferndale, 596 F. Supp. 2d 1027, 1028 (E.D. Mich. 2008) (striking down city's ordinances that, in part, prohibited the display of signs asking motorists to "honk" their horns to express their support for the demonstrators).  Courts have repeatedly held that the government should not suppress the speech of a speaker because of the response to the speech, but rather should address the reaction to the speech (here, the actions of the motorist).  See, e.g., Van Arnam v. GSA, 332 F. Supp. 2d 376, 402 (D. Mass. 2004) ("Courts have held that when the cost to the speaker of using the forum location is made to depend not only on expenses for which she may be directly responsible, but also for the expenses potentially created by counterdemonstrators and others over whom she has no control, an unconstitutional 'heckler's veto' can be created.") (citing Forsyth Cty. v. Nationalist Movement, 505 U.S. 123, 134-35 (1992)).  For these reasons, Defendant Motion should be denied as to Plaintiff's First Amendment claim.
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff Theresa M. Petrello respectfully requests that this Court deny Defendant Officer Ryan J. Brandreth's Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings.5

top_links.moving_heading: a. Qualified immunity and the First Amendment.
top_links.moving_content: The Plaintiff's right to attempt to stop moving traffic that has a green light to reach into the roadway and take items from the driver is not a clearly established right under the First Amendment. Cutting v. City of Portland, supra, is inapposite. In Cutting, the city of Portland, Maine banned all persons from standing on all traffic islands in the city. At the least, such a reasonable interpretation of the statute would not put a reasonable police officer on notice that he was violating the Plaintiff's First Amendment rights, and qualified immunity should apply to this claim as to the individual officer.

top_links.moving_heading: C.  There was no violation of the Fourth Amendment in a brief stop to issue the Plaintiff a ticket.
top_links.moving_content:
What should be clear from the Complaint was the Plaintiff was not arrested.  She was a pedestrian.  The officer came up to her, explained that she could not cause obstructions to traffic where there is a green light and she is causing a vehicle to stop, and issued her a "ticket."  The statute that the Plaintiff was cited under was RSA 644:2(II)(c), which provides that a person is guilty of disorderly conduct if:
"II.  He or she:
(c) Obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any public street or sidewalk or the entrance to any public building."
A police stop only becomes unreasonable if the time needed to handle the matter exceeds what is reasonable.  A seizure justified only by a police observed traffic violation becomes unlawful if it is prolonged beyond the time reasonably required to complete the mission of issuing a ticket for the violation. Rodriguez v. United States, 135 S.Ct. 1609, 1612 (2015).  The Plaintiff was never arrested in this case.  All that occurred was a temporary detention or a seizure. Where the officer has a reasonable concern about potential criminal activity based on his on the spot observations, and where immediate action is required to ensure that any criminal activity is stopped or prevented, the officer may stop the subject.  All that is required for such a stop is a belief that the circumstances gave rise to a reasonable suspicion of criminal activity. Schubert v. City of Springfield, 589 F.3d 496, 502 (1st Cir. 2009).  As the Plaintiff alleges in her Complaint, with citation to Officer Brandreth's police report which is attached to Exhibit C to the Complaint, "during a green light cycle for vehicles traveling north on Maple Street a black Cadillac came to a complete stop and handed [Ms. Petrello] something.  The vehicle then traveled north through the intersection.  The vehicle behind it . . . had to stop because the Cadillac stopped.  The light turned red and the Cherokee was unable to make it through on the green light cycle and would not have had to wait for the next light cycle." ¶23. The Plaintiff further alleges that during the interaction Officer Brandreth, "told Ms. Petrello that she could not stop vehicles." ¶24. The Plaintiff then alleges that Officer Brandreth, issued Ms. Petrello a summons to appear in Manchester District Court on July 9, 2015 for one count of disorderly conduct for obstructing vehicular traffic under RSA 644:2(II)(c). ¶25. The allegation is that there was a brief conversation between she and Officer Brandreth and she was issued a ticket to appear in court.  Further, the allegation is that Ms. Petrello was attempting to get vehicles to stop, that was her purpose on the sidewalk, and that a vehicle in fact stopped, even though it had the green light, causing another vehicle to stop behind it even though traffic had the right of way with the green light, and causing the second vehicle to miss the traffic cycle. The sole reason for the vehicle that obstructed traffic behind it to stop was Ms. Petrello's solicitation, and no other allegation is made as to any other reason why the vehicle would stop.  Accordingly under simple "but for" causation analysis, Ms. Petrello was causing an obstruction in traffic and therefore violated the disorderly conduct statute.  However, for immediate purposes here under a Fourth Amendment analysis, all that Officer Brandreth needed was a reasonable suspicion to stop Ms. Petrello because she was obstructing traffic, and that was satisfied.  Accordingly, there was no Fourth Amendment violation by Officer Brandreth.
In an analogous case, the Supreme Court of Washington found that application of a Washington ordinance that made it unlawful to intentionally obstruct vehicle traffic was constitutional and was not void for vagueness, and did not violate the Equal Protection Clause when a panhandler brought a challenge to it (for what was apparently obstruction of pedestrian as opposed to vehicular traffic).  A key factor in the decision was that the obstructing activity was intentional. Seattle v. Webster, 802 P.2d 1334 (1990).

Here, Defendant, as he must, concedes that Plaintiff was seized.  Plaintiff also claims that the summons, itself, lacked probable cause.
Under the disorderly conduct statute, "[a] person is guilty of disorderly conduct if: ... He or she: ... (c) Obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any public street or sidewalk or the entrance to any public building.").  See RSA 644:2(II)(c) (emphasis added). Consistent with the allegations in the Second Amended Complaint, video Plaintiff produced in discovery reveals that Defendant's detention of Plaintiff was based solely on (i) Plaintiff's speech to passing motorists asking them to make a donation and (ii) a motorist's reaction to her speech, which Defendant claimed was obstructing the roadway.  According to the video, Plaintiff was stopped "[b]ased on your behavior ... by being out here with a sign panhandling for money, having a car stop, and then not allowing the second car who was not able to get through the intersection that it should have ...."  See Exhibit 1 (emphasis added).2  Thus, the question here is whether it would be objectively reasonable for Defendant Officer Brandreth to suspect that a peaceful panhandler soliciting motorists from a public place is "obstructing" traffic simply when a car slows down or stops in response to the panhandler's specific speech asking for a donation.
As is clear by using both common sense and examining the disorderly conduct statute's plain terms, a peaceful panhandler soliciting donations from motorists in a public place is not obstructing traffic, regardless of how the motorist responds.  According to Black's Law Dictionary, to "obstruct" means "[t]o block up; to interpose obstacles; to render impassable; to fill with barriers or impediments; as to obstruct a road or way."  See "Obstruct," Black's Law Dictionary, available at http://thelawdictionary.org/obstruct/.  A peaceful panhandler in a public place engaging in speech directed at motorists is not "blocking," "interposing obstacles," "rendering impassable" or "filling with barriers or impediments" in a roadway.  To the extent anyone is obstructing a roadway, it would be the motorist who makes the independent, intervening decision to slow down or stop his car and make a donation-not the panhandler who is simply conveying a peaceful message adjacent to the roadway.  Under Defendant's theory, a teenager on a public place adjacent to a roadway would be criminally liable for disorderly conduct when a motorist slows down in response to the teenager's speech simply asking (whether it be verbally or through a sign) motorists to pull over or make a turn to buy lemonade or have their car washed.  Like Plaintiff's speech, this speech is obviously not obstructive where a speaker is not impeding someone's right of way and not causing the motorist to take evasive action.  See Human v. Colarusso, No. 13-cv-296-SM, 2015 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4866, at *4, 12, 2015 DNH 012 (D.N.H. Jan. 15, 2015) (noting that plaintiff "obstructed pedestrian traffic at that intersection" when he "forc[ed] people to walk around his display to access the crosswalk"). Indeed, under Defendant's extreme "but/for" causation theory, the owner of a sign on a median or a billboard telling a motorist to turn left on a single-lane road to enter a business could create an obstruction on a roadway when the driver slows down or even stops to make the turn in response to the speech.  Under this example, the speaker-here, the sign or billboard owner-would have violated the law simply because of how the motorist responded to his or her protected speech.  As a matter of common sense, this is obviously incorrect because (i) the speaker is not in the road doing the obstructing and (ii) there is an intervening act that severs any semblance of causation-namely, the free will of the motorist deciding to slow down or stop.3
The crux of Defendant's argument seems to be that he is entitled to qualified immunity because the term "obstruction" has not been defined by case law.  While it is true that the New Hampshire Supreme Court has not interpreted the term "obstruction," the qualified immunity analysis "does not require a case directly on point."  Glik, 655 F.3d at 81.  A regulation or statute is sufficient in determining the contours of a legal right.  Put another way, the command of a statute is itself "clearly established law."  See Santana v. Calderon, 342 F.3d 18, 23 (1st Cir. 2003) ("The defendants are entitled to qualified immunity unless (1) the facts alleged show the defendants' conduct violated a constitutional right, and (2) the contours of this right are 'clearly established' under then-existing law so that a reasonable officer would have known that his conduct was unlawful."); see also Davis v. Scherer, 468 U.S. 183, 194 n.12 (1984) ("officials become liable for damages only to the extent that there is a clear violation of the statutory rights that give rise to the cause of action for damages") (emphasis added); Hope v. Pelzer, 536 U.S. 730, 733 (2002) (guards' conduct in twice handcuffing the plaintiff to a hitching post to sanction him for disorderly conduct violated clearly established rights of which a reasonable person would have known; decision based, in part, on regulation authority).  Of course, the most egregious violations of rights may not engender legal opinions or may not even happen at all.  This is why statutes and regulations can, by themselves, define the contours of legal rights and prevent qualified immunity when these clearly- established rights are violated.
Finally, determining whether qualified immunity exists here is also premature.  For example, Defendant's Motion cannot be fully examined without further discovery into how the Manchester Police Department has historically interpreted the disorderly conduct law applied against Plaintiff. To the extent Officer Brandreth's interpretation is not one that he or the Department has historically applied, that would tend to support the fact that the Officer's application of this statute is novel and deviated from its plain terms.  The evidence in this case is likely to reveal-as alleged in the Second Amended Complaint and its exhibits-that this interpretation is entirely new and was only recently adopted in approximately 2015.  Discovery may also reveal that Officer Brandreth has never applied his interpretation to, for example, teenagers on the side of the road soliciting motorists to buy an item or have their car washed-facts which would further demonstrate how this interpretation as applied to panhandlers is a selective distortion of an otherwise clear statute.  Given this reality, Defendant's request for qualified immunity would be best raised in a Motion for Summary Judgment after the close of discovery.  See DeMayo v. Nugent, 517 F.3d 11, 19 (1st Cir. 2008) ("If Nugent and Lugas wished to present evidence of additional facts that might refute or undermine DeMayo's pleadings, the place to do so was in their response to his motion.").

top_links.moving_heading: A.  Motion to Dismiss For Failure To Join An Indispensable Party
top_links.response_heading: I. THIS LIMITED CASE CAN PROCEED WITHOUT JUSTRITE.
top_links.response_content:
The Sofield Parties contend that the Complaint should be dismissed because Justrite is both "necessary" and "indispensable" under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 19.1  (Defendants' MTD at 9.)  Not so.  As a general matter, plaintiffs have broad discretion to structure litigation as they see fit, and federal courts are "extremely reluctant" to dismiss cases based on nonjoinder unless "the defect cannot be cured and serious prejudice or inefficiency will result." RPR & Assocs. v. O'Brien/Atkins Assocs., P.A., 921 F. Supp. 1457, 1463 (M.D.N.C. 1995) (the state was not a necessary party in an action by a contractor on state university construction project against architect and consulting engineer).
Rule 19 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure sets forth a two-step inquiry for compulsory joinder.  First, under Rule 19(a), a court must assess whether the absent party is "required" in the action. Second, if the court determines that the party is required, then, under Rule 19(b), the court must determine whether the case can proceed without that party or must be dismissed. Courts conduct this analysis "pragmatically, in the context of the 'substance' of each case, rather than by procedural formula."  Provident Tradesmens Bank & Trust Co. v. Patterson, 390 U.S. 102, 119 n. 16 (1968). A pragmatic analysis of U.S. Bank's Complaint demonstrates that this action can proceed without Justrite.

top_links.moving_heading: B. Motions to Dismiss for Failure to State a Claim Upon Which Relief Can Be Granted
top_links.moving_content: When considering a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court must accept the plaintiff's factual allegations as true and draw all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff's favor, but need not accept legal conclusions or unreasonable inferences.  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678, 129 S. Ct. 1937, 173 L. Ed. 2d 868 (2009); E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. v. Kolon Indus., 637 F.3d 435, 440 (4th Cir.2011). "To survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint must contain sufficient factual matter, accepted as true, to state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face." Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678 (quoting Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570, 127 S. Ct. 1955, 167 L. Ed. 2d 929 (2007)). "Threadbare recitals of the elements of a cause of action, supported by mere conclusory statements, do not suffice." Id.; Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555.  "Facts pled that are 'merely consistent with' liability are not sufficient." A Soc'y Without a Name v. Virginia, 655 F.3d 342, 346 (4th Cir.) (quoting Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678).

top_links.moving_heading: A.  The Complaint Should Be Dismissed For Failure to Join An Indispensable Party
top_links.moving_content:
Justrite is a necessary party to this action because it is a real party in interest and permitting this suit to continue in its absence almost certainly will subject the Sofield Parties to conflicting legal obligations and an unnecessary multiplicity of lawsuits.  The funds at issue in this case do not belong to U.S. Bank, and U.S. Bank "does not have a stake in vindicating the alleged rights" of the real parties in interest, Justrite and the Sofield Parties.  Berkeley Acquisitions, LLC v. Mallow, Konstam & Hager, P.C., 262 F.R.D. 269 (S.D.N.Y. 2009). "Merely stakeholders or escrow agents which are not subject to liability in the lawsuit are not real parties to the action . . . "  Id., 262 F.R.D. at 273 (dismissing action brought by escrow agent for failure to join two of the real parties in interest to the transaction at issue).
Further, this Court will have to interpret the Escrow Agreement and the Purchase Agreement in order to resolve any such dispute as there is between the Sofield Parties and U.S. Bank; yet these same interpretations will need to be made by a court resolving the dispute that presumably will follow - regardless of the outcome of this lawsuit -- between the Sofield Parties and Justrite.  An increased potential for inconsistent judgments is grounds for finding a party necessary under Rule 19(a).  See Owens-Illinois, Inc. v. Meade, 186 F.3d 435, 441-442 (4th Cir.
1999); Teamsters Local Union No. 171 v. Keal Driveaway Co., 173 F.3d 915 (4th Cir. 1999); Schlumberger Indus., Inc. v. National Sur. Corp., 36 F.3d 1274, 1286 (4th Cir. 1994).
Thus, Justrite is a "necessary" party and should be joined in this action if feasible.  Of course, it would be proper for this Court to order U.S. Bank to join Justrite in this suit if such is feasible.  In the event Justrite cannot be joined, however, the Court must consider whether Justrite is an "indispensable" party so that this action must be dismissed.
As a party to the contracts in dispute in this action and the only party other than the Sofield Parties with a real interest in the hundreds of thousands of dollars at issue, Justrite is both a necessary and indispensable party.  See Berkeley Acquisitions, LLC, supra, 262 F.R.D. at 273 (finding that the other parties to a contract were indispensable in an action on one party's claims to money held in escrow, and quoting Crouse-Hinds Co. v. InterNorth, Inc., 634 F.2d 690, 701 (2d Cir. 1980) ("No procedural principle is more deeply imbedded in the common law than that, in an action to set aside a lease or a contract, all parties who may be affected by the determination of the action are indispensable.")
Resolution of U.S. Bank's claims will require the Court to determine the rights of U.S. Bank, Justrite, and the Sofield Parties under the Escrow Agreement and the Purchase Agreement. For example, the Sofield Parties will defend against U.S. Bank's claims on the merits on grounds that U.S. Bank did not distribute the escrowed funds to them either "inadvertently" or improperly, but in fact properly distributed them because Justrite's purported "Pending Claim Notice" was patently deficient and ineffective on its face under the terms of the Escrow Agreement. 4  Accordingly, U.S. Bank was required to make the final distribution pursuant to §5.3 of the Escrow Agreement.
The Sofield Parties will also defend U.S. Bank's claims on the merits on grounds that nothing in the Escrow Agreement obliged them to return any monies once such were distributed to them; that the Escrow Agreement terminated of its own terms once the final distribution was made; 5 that U.S. Bank has no obligation to seek return of the distributed funds and is proceeding as a mere volunteer in this lawsuit; 6 and that the Purchase Agreement specifically contemplates and provides that Justrite is to seek recourse for any such indemnification claim as it purports to have directly against the Sofield Companies since there are no longer any funds in escrow. 7
These same or similar arguments will be made in any litigation subsequently brought by Justrite (whether against the Sofield Parties and/or U.S. Bank) to dispute the right of the Sofield Parties to the final distribution of the escrowed funds and to assert its purported indemnification claim.  And if Justrite is not joined as a party in this action, Justrite will be entitled to re-litigate any determination made on these issues by this Court in this action.  The Sofield Parties will thus be exposed to multiple and potentially inconsistent judicial determinations on the same issues.
If the Sofield Parties prevail in this case, Justrite is still free to pursue them directly in another lawsuit on claims that the Sofield Parties must return the final escrowed amounts to U.S. Bank for escrow and that they are responsible to indemnify Justrite for the purported I-9 documentation issues.  If U.S. Bank prevails on its claims, it will subsequently have to bring an interpleader action, and the Sofield Parties will have to litigate their right to the escrowed funds again.  Either way, the Sofield Parties will be subject to multiple lawsuits regarding the same fundamental issues, imposing upon it the substantial risk of inconsistent judgments and unnecessary litigation.
Further, there is no suggestion that Justrite (and U.S. Bank, to the extent it is found to have any real interest in this dispute) would not have an adequate remedy by proceeding in the North Carolina state courts.  Justrite is apparently engaged in operations in North Carolina, as it purchased the Sofield Parties' business operations in the state, and can easily litigate in the state courts.  Most if not all of the witnesses and documents that would be pertinent to the dispute between Justrite and the Sofield Parties are located in North Carolina, and the state court is fully capable of rendering a fair decision among these North Carolina residents.  See Owens-Illinois, Inc. v. Meade, 186 F.3d 435, 441-442 (4th Cir. 1999) ("[W]e see no reason why the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West Virginia will not provide an adequate remedy for the parties in this case. In fact, it is likely the best place for the adjudication of this matter since all of the Plaintiffs work at the same location and will share many witnesses and exhibits in the event a trial is held.  The West Virginia state court is more than capable of rendering an adequate and fair judgment in this matter.")
In sum, Justrite should be determined an "indispensable' party under Rule 19(b) and, unless U.S. Bank can join Justrite as a party, this action should be dismissed.
top_links.response_heading: B. Even if Justrite Were a "Required" Party and Could Not Be Joined, the Action Should Proceed Under Rule 19(b).
top_links.response_content:
Because Justrite is not a required party to the action under Rule 19(a), the Court need not reach the Rule 19(b) analysis.  But if the Court were to find Justrite to be a required party and in the event that Justrite could not be joined, then the Court would have to "determine whether, in equity and good conscience, the action should proceed among the existing parties or should be dismissed."  Fed. R. Civ. P. 19(b).  The factors to be considered in conducting that assessment include:
(1)  the extent to which a judgment rendered in the person's absence might prejudice that person or the existing parties;
(2)  the extent to which any prejudice could be lessened or avoided by: (A) protective provisions in the judgment; (B) shaping the relief; or (C) other measures;
(3)  whether a judgment rendered in the person's absence would be adequate; and
(4)  whether the plaintiff would have an adequate remedy if the action were dismissed for nonjoinder. Id.
The Sofield Parties claim that "[r]esolution of U.S. Bank's claims will require the Court to determine the rights of U.S. Bank, Justrite, and the Sofield Parties under the Escrow Agreement and the Purchase Agreement."  (Defendants' MTD at 9.)  That is simply not the case: There's no reason for the Court to have to interpret the Purchase Agreement-U.S. Bank is not a party to that Agreement and has no interest in any dispute over it-or to determine Justrite's rights.2
The Sofield Parties also contend that Justrite is "indispensable" because the arguments that the Sofield Parties will assert in this case will be the "same or similar" to arguments that they might make in any subsequent litigation with Justrite. (Id.)  Specifically, the Sofield Parties claim that they intend to defend this case on the grounds that:
• "U.S. Bank was required to make the final distribution pursuant to §5.3 of the Escrow Agreement"
• "nothing in the Escrow Agreement obliged [the Sofield Parties] to return any monies once such were distributed to them"
• "the Escrow Agreement terminated of its own terms once the final distribution was made"
• "U.S. Bank has no obligation to seek return of the distributed funds..."
• "the Purchase Agreement specifically contemplates and provides that Justrite is to seek recourse for any such indemnification claim as it purports to have directly against the Sofield Parties since there are no longer any funds in escrow."
(Defendants' MTD at 10.)
Contrary to the Sofield Parties' claim, those arguments have nothing to do with whether Justrite could successfully pursue indemnification from the Sofield Parties for breaching the Purchase Agreement-the crux of the underlying dispute between Justrite and the Sofield Parties. Returning the money to U.S. Bank pending resolution of the underlying dispute is completely consistent with an ultimate finding for either party, including that the Sofield Parties are, in fact, entitled to the funds.
Neither the Sofield Parties nor Justrite is prejudiced by U.S. Bank's holding the disputed funds to ensure that they are available to whichever party prevails in the underlying dispute.  The Court should deny the Sofield Parties' Rule 12(b)(7) motion to dismiss the Complaint because Justrite is neither "necessary" nor "indispensable."

top_links.moving_heading: 1.  Plaintiff Cannot State a Valid Claim for Conversion
top_links.moving_content:
"There are . . . two essential elements of a conversion claim: ownership in the plaintiff and wrongful possession or conversion by the defendant. Variety Wholesalers, Inc. v. Salem Logistics Traffic Servs., LLC, 365 N.C. 520, 523, 723 S.E.2d 744, 747 (N.C. 2012); see also Gadson v. Toney, 69 N.C. App. 244, 246, 316 S.E.2d 320, 321-322 (N.C. Ct. App. 1984) ("To recover on a claim for conversion, plaintiff must prove both ownership in himself and the wrongful possession or conversion of the property by the defendant.") (citing Coulbourn v. Armstrong, 243 N.C. 663, 91 S.E. 2d 912 (1956)).
U.S. Bank does not allege that it owns the funds that it distributed from escrow to the Sofield Parties that are at issue in this action.  To the contrary, it alleges that it was an escrow agent with respect to such funds, which by definition means it had no ownership interest in them. Accordingly, U.S. Bank has not and cannot assert a claim for conversion.
top_links.response_heading: II. U.S. BANK HAS STATED A CLAIM FOR CONVERSION.
top_links.response_content:
A claim for conversion has two elements: (1) plaintiff's ownership of the property; and (2) the defendant's "wrongful possession or conversion" to his own use. Variety Wholesalers, Inc. v. Salem Logistics Traffic Servs., LLC, 723 S.E.2d 744, 747 (N.C. 2012) (internal citations omitted).  The Sofield Parties argue that U.S. Bank's status as an escrow agent precludes it from asserting that claim on the grounds that "by definition" an escrow agent has "no ownership interest" in the escrowed funds.  (Defendants' MTD at 12.)  That is not the law in North Carolina.
A "bailee has such an interest in the property in his possession as entitles him to maintain an action against third parties for damage to or conversion of the property." Peed, 89 S.E.2d at 257 (holding that bailor and bailee could maintain a joint action against purchaser for alleged conversion of shipment of potatoes) (internal citations omitted).  In Peed, the North Carolina Supreme Court noted that "had either [bailor] or [bailee] instituted the action in his own name alone he would hold the recovery in trust for the other party to the extent of the interest of such party in the property converted."3 Id. at 258; see also Kawa v. United States, 77 Fed.Cl. 294, 301 (2007) (escrow agent had standing to sue government to recover purchase order payment that government sent directly to contractor).
U.S. Bank has alleged facts sufficient to establish both elements of conversion:
• Justrite submitted a Pending Claim Notice to U.S. Bank requesting that U.S. Bank not release any of the escrow funds. (Compl. ¶ 22.)
• The Sofield Parties did not submit an objection to the Pending Claim Notice during the Objection Period.  (Compl. ¶ 23.)
• U.S. Bank inadvertently distributed the disputed escrow funds to the Sofield Parties.  (Compl. ¶ 24.)
• The distribution of those remaining escrow funds was an error. (Compl. ¶ 25.)
• Upon realizing the error, U.S. Bank demanded the return of the escrow funds in a letter dated May 15, 2015, pending the resolution of the underlying claim. (Compl. ¶ 26.)
• The Sofield Parties refused to return the money. (Compl. ¶¶ 30-31.)
Simply put, U.S. Bank's role as an escrow agent is no barrier-as a matter of law-to the assertion of its conversion claim, and U.S. Bank has alleged specific facts that state a claim for conversion. The Court should, therefore, dismiss the Sofield Parties' motion to dismiss the conversion claim.

top_links.moving_heading: 2. Plaintiff Cannot State a Valid Claim for Unjust Enrichment
top_links.moving_content:
In order to establish a claim for unjust enrichment, a plaintiff must allege: (1) it conferred a measurable benefit on the other party; (2) that party consciously accepted the benefit, and (3) the benefit was not conferred officiously or gratuitously. Booe v. Shadrick, 322 N.C. 567, 369 S.E.2d 554, 556 (N.C. 1988); Primerica Life Ins. Co. v. James Massengill & Sons Const. Co., 211 N.C. App. 252, 712 S.E.2d 670, 677 (N.C. App. 2011). Further, "a claim for unjust enrichment may not be brought in the face of an express contractual relationship between the parties." Madison River Mgmt. Co. v. Bus. Mgmt. Software Corp., 351 F. Supp. 2d 436, 446 (M.D.N.C. 2005) (citing Se. Shelter Corp. v. BTU, Inc., 154 N.C. App. 321, 572 S.E.2d 200, 206 (N.C. App. 2002)).
Here, the Escrow Agreement governs the relationship between U.S. Bank and the Sofield Parties.  Accordingly, U.S. Bank may not maintain a claim for unjust enrichment under North Carolina law.
Even if the claim were not barred in light of the Escrow Agreement, U.S. Bank's claim for unjust enrichment would fail.  "Not every enrichment of one by the voluntary act of another is unjust. 'Where a person has officiously conferred a benefit upon another, the other is enriched but is not considered to be unjustly enriched. The recipient of a benefit voluntarily bestowed without solicitation or inducement is not liable for their value.'"  Wright v. Wright, 305 N.C. 345, 350, 289 S.E.2d 347, 351 (N.C. 1982) (quoting Rhyne v. Sheppard, 224 N.C. 734, 737, 32 S.E. 2d 316, 318 (1944).
The complaint makes clear that in this case, the Sofield Parties did not solicit or induce U.S. Bank to distribute the remaining escrow funds to them.  U.S. Bank "officiously" distributed the funds to the Sofield Parties wholly on its own instance.  Further, U.S. Bank did not distribute any "benefit" that it owned and for which it could be entitled to compensation; it acted merely as an escrow agent distributing money rightfully belonging to another.  U.S. Bank fails to state a valid claim for unjust enrichment.
top_links.response_heading: III. U.S. BANK HAS STATED A CLAIM FOR UNJUST ENRICHMENT.
top_links.response_content:
U.S. Bank has adequately alleged unjust enrichment.  To recover under an unjust enrichment theory, the plaintiff must have conferred a measurable benefit on the defendant, and the benefit must not have been conferred "officiously"-by interfering in the affairs of the other party-or "gratuitously."  Britt v. Britt, 359 S.E.2d 467, 469 (N.C. 1987).  As alleged in the Complaint, U.S. Bank mistakenly disbursed the disputed funds to the Sofield Parties after receiving a Pending Claim Notice from Justrite and then notified the Sofield Parties of the mistake.  (Compl. ¶¶ 25-26.) The disbursement was a measurable benefit and was not made as a gift or to interfere in the Sofield Parties' affairs (notwithstanding the Sofield Parties' naked claim that U.S. Bank "'officiously' distributed the funds to the Sofield Parties wholly on its own instance [sic]").  (Defendants' MTD at 13.)
The Sofield Parties contend that U.S. Bank's unjust enrichment claim must be dismissed because there was an express contractual relationship between the parties (i.e., the Escrow Agreement).   But U.S. Bank may plead equitable claims in the alternative.  See, e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a)(3) ("A pleading that states a claim for relief must contain . . . a demand for the relief sought, which may include relief in the alternative or different types of relief.").  The Sofield Parties argue that upon U.S. Bank's distribution of the remaining escrowed funds to the Sofield Parties, the Escrow Agreement terminated.  (Defendants' MTD at 10.)  If the Sofield Parties are correct, then the contract wouldn't bar U.S. Bank's equitable remedy for the Sofield Parties' post-contractual conduct.
Under Section 6 of the Escrow Agreement, the Agreement "shall terminate on the first to occur of (a) the disbursement of the entire amount of the Escrow Funds in accordance with the terms hereof or (b) a mutual consent signed by Purchaser and the Sellers' Representative."  Although the Complaint alleges that the disbursement of the disputed funds was inadvertent (Compl. ¶ 25), the Sofield Parties argue that the contract terminated upon the disbursement of the funds (Defendants' MTD at 10).  In that case, the Sofield Parties' actions (holding the funds) arose post-contract and are, therefore, not governed by the contract.
The general rule that an express contract precludes a claim for unjust enrichment does not apply where "the implied agreement is based upon the conduct of the parties subsequent to, and not covered by, the terms of the express contract." Schuck Corp. v. Sorkowitz, 686 P.2d 1366, 1368 (Colo. Ct. App. 1984) (reversing and remanding trial court judgment because defendants' behavior post-contract "impl[ied] a contract substantially different from that covered by the express [contract]"); Ford Motor Co. v. Ghreiwati Auto, 945 F. Supp. 2d 851, 854 (E.D. Mich. 2013) (declining to dismiss unjust enrichment claim even though an express contract existed); Dansbury v. EOG Res., Inc., No. 3:12-cv-00391, 2014 WL 2737841, at *13 (M.D. Pa. June 13, 2014) (where benefits were obtained after lease expired, they can only be recovered through a quasi-contract remedy).

top_links.moving_heading: 3.  Plaintiff Has Not Alleged Facts Sufficient To Establish an "Actual Controversy" As to Which This Court Properly Could Issue a Declaratory Judgment
top_links.moving_content:
Finally, U.S. Bank requests a "declaratory judgment" with respect to the parties "respective rights and duties," by which it presumably means the parties' respective rights and duties under the Escrow Agreement and Purchase Agreement.  U.S. Bank's allegations do not establish an "actual controversy" between these parties as to which a declaratory judgment could properly be issued. 8
"[A] federal court may properly exercise jurisdiction in a declaratory judgment proceeding when three essentials are met: (1) the complaint alleges an 'actual controversy' between the parties 'of sufficient immediacy and reality to warrant issuance of a declaratory judgment;' (2) the court possesses an independent basis for jurisdiction over the parties (e.g., federal question or diversity jurisdiction); 9 and (3) the court does not abuse its discretion in its exercise of jurisdiction."  Volvo Constr. Equip. N. Am., Inc. v. CLM Equip. Co., 386 F.3d 581, 593 (4th Cir. 2004).  An "actual controversy" may exist where a plaintiff seeks a declaratory judgment in order to avoid the accrual of "avoidable damages."  See id. (citing NUCOR Corp. v. Aceros Y Maquilas de Occidente, 28 F.3d 572, 577 (7th Cir. 1994)). U.S. Bank fails to make any allegations identifying the potential liability or damage that it seeks to avoid that would entitle it to a declaratory judgment.  Nor do its allegations show how such a judgment entered by this Court as between the existing parties - U.S. Bank and the Sofield Parties - could provide it with relief with respect to such potential liability or damage.
The complaint and the exhibits attached to the complaint make clear that the Sofield Parties have no grounds to sue U.S. Bank and have never threatened litigation against U.S.
Bank.  Thus, there is no potential liability or damages claimed by the Sofield Parties that U.S. Bank seeks to avoid or have clarified.
Any liability that U.S. Bank might seek to avoid in this lawsuit would be a liability not to the Sofield Parties but to Justrite.  Yet U.S. Bank fails to allege any facts concerning any possible litigation by Justrite against it - much less establish that such litigation "appears to be unavoidable."  Moreover, even if litigation was threatened by Justrite, any potential liability of U.S. Bank to Justrite is both speculative and remote. 10  Further, the action taken by U.S. Bank that could give rise to liability (the release of the escrowed funds) has already occurred and could not occur again, so as lead to the accrual of additional damages, as U.S. Bank no longer holds any escrowed funds. 11
In any event, and more to the point, any determination by this Court as to whether (i) U.S. Bank had any right or obligation to withhold escrowed funds, and (ii) the Sofield Parties have any obligation to return funds already distributed to them will not have any binding effect upon Justrite, as it is not a party to this lawsuit and could not be bound by the Court's determinations.  Thus, any declaratory judgment by this Court is likely to amount to a mere advisory opinion, having no binding effect on Justrite in any subsequent suit it brings against either U.S. Bank or the Sofield Parties, except insofar as the Court's decision suits Justrite's purposes and is later used by it against either of those parties.  In effect, U.S. Bank and Justrite would get to take two bites at the same apple against the Sofield Parties.  For the Sofield Parties, on the other hand, this action would bring neither certainty nor finality, but only the expense of duplicative litigation and the risk of inconsistent legal determinations.
In sum, there is no "actual controversy" between U.S. Bank and the Sofield Parties that threatens U.S. Bank with the accrual of avoidable damages.  Any damages or liability of U.S. Bank would be as the result of a controversy between it and Justrite, and is both wholly speculative and not properly determined in this action, where Justrite has not been joined as a party.  Under these circumstances, a declaratory judgment is not proper in any event.
WHEREFORE, Defendants respectfully request that the Court grant their Motion to Dismiss and DISMISS Plaintiff's Complaint.
top_links.response_heading: IV. U.S. BANK HAS ALLEGED AN ACTUAL CONTROVERSY OVER WHICH THE COURT HAS JURISDICTION TO ENTER A DECLARATORY JUDGMENT.
top_links.response_content:
The Sofield Parties raise a jurisdictional objection to U.S. Bank's claim for a declaratory judgment.  (Defendants' MTD at 14 n. 8.)  The Court should reject that challenge.  The Declaratory Judgment Act provides that "[i]n a case of actual controversy within its jurisdiction, . . . any court of the United States, upon the filing of an appropriate pleading, may declare the rights and other legal relations of any interested party seeking such declaration, whether or not further relief is or could be sought." 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a). "[A] federal court may properly exercise jurisdiction in a declaratory judgment proceeding when three essentials are met: (1) the complaint alleges an 'actual controversy' between the parties 'of sufficient immediacy and reality to warrant issuance of a declaratory judgment;' (2) the court possesses an independent basis for jurisdiction over the parties (e.g., federal question or diversity jurisdiction); and (3) the court does not abuse its discretion in its exercise of jurisdiction." Volvo Constr. Equip. N. Am., Inc. v. CLM Equip. Co., 386 F.3d 581, 592 (4th Cir. 2004) (finding declaratory judgment proper) (internal citations omitted). None of these requirements is an obstacle to entering a declaratory judgment in this case.
First, there is currently a live, concrete dispute between U.S. Bank, on the one hand, and the Sofield Parties on the other hand.  The Complaint alleges that the Sofield Parties are in possession of the disputed funds and that U.S. Bank is entitled to immediate possession of them pending resolution of Justrite's indemnification claims.  This is not an academic undertaking, and U.S. Bank has standing to seek a declaratory judgment by virtue of its role as escrow agent.
Second, the Court has diversity jurisdiction over this action, because the Sofield Parties are citizens of North Carolina, U.S. Bank is a citizen of Minnesota and Ohio, and the amount in controversy exceeds $75,000.
Third, it would be entirely proper for the Court to exercise its discretion to enter a declaratory judgment. While doing so will not resolve all disputes as between the Sofield Parties and Justrite, it will resolve this dispute between U.S. Bank and the Sofield Parties over the inadvertently released funds.
The Court should exercise its discretion to deny the Sofield Parties' motion to dismiss U.S. Bank's claim for declaratory judgment.

top_links.moving_heading: B. Count I: "Violation of RESPA" Claim Should be Dismissed
top_links.moving_content:
The request for information sent to BANA by Plaintiff does not constitute a proper QWR; thus, Plaintiff's claim should be dismissed.  To the extent the Court deems Plaintiff's request to be sufficient, BANA timely acknowledged and responded to Plaintiff's request.  [See Exhibit I and J to Plaintiff's Complaint, ¶¶ 48 and 49 of Plaintiff's Complaint, and Exhibit 1 to this Motion].
To constitute a proper QWR, the writing must "include a statement of the reasons for the belief of the borrower, to the extent applicable, that the account is in error or provides sufficient detail to the servicer regarding other information sought by the borrower." 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(B).  Letters that "merely dispute a debt or request information are not 'qualified written requests,' and do not trigger the obligations under section 2605." Catalan v. GMAC Mort. Corp., 629 F.3d 676, 686 (7th Cir. 2011) (internal citations omitted). Here, the letter sent by Plaintiff, merely states that he "make(s) this request, based on our dispute of the amounts due and owing stated on/by your Complaint."  The letter goes on to list 13 categories of documents it would like to review.  This type of request is not sufficient to constitute a QWR as it merely disputes the debt and does not include a statement of the reason the borrower believes the account is in error, nor does it contain sufficient detail to allow BANA to review the account for potential errors in servicing. 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(B); Catalan, 629 F.3d at 686.  Therefore, Plaintiff's claim that BANA violated RESPA fails and should be dismissed.
Even if this Court determines Plaintiff's letter constitutes a proper QWR, Plaintiff's claim still fails because BANA timely responded to Plaintiff's request, within 20 days of receipt of Plaintiff's letter, and this is within the appropriate time frame under 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(A). Within 20 days of receiving a QWR, a servicer must send a written acknowledgement of the request. See 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(A). Within 60 days after receiving a qualified written request, the servicer must, among other options, investigate the borrower's account and either provide the requested information or provide an explanation as to why the requested information is unavailable. See 12 U.S.C. §2605(e)(2)(C).  Here, Plaintiff admits that the October 4, 2011, letter sent by Blank Rome, LLP, on BANA's behalf is responsive to the alleged QWR request, but seems to suggest that the response was not timely sent.  [See ¶49 of Plaintiff's Complaint]. Plaintiff's allegations are misleading; he alleges that the QWR was sent to BANA on June 21, 2011, however Plaintiff's allegation is betrayed by Plaintiff's own exhibit.  [See Exhibit I to Plaintiff's Complaint].  The last page of Plaintiff's Exhibit I shows that Plaintiff did not sign the letter until July 5, 2011, not June 21, 2011, as stated in the Complaint.  [Id.].  Additionally, both BANA's acknowledgment letter and response letter indicate the QWR was received on July 11, 2011.  [See Exhibit I to Plaintiff's Complaint and Exhibit 1 to this Motion].  Thus the response, to the extent this was a valid QWR request in the first place, which it was not, was timely returned.
Pursuant to 12 U.S.C. 2605(a)(1)(A) and (2), the calculation of time excludes "legal public holidays, Saturdays and Sundays."  BANA's acknowledgement and response were both sent within the time allowed: the acknowledgement letter was sent nine days after receiving the QWR and the response letter was sent 60 days after receiving the QWR (excluding Labor Day, and all Saturdays and Sundays).  Plaintiff's claim should be dismissed for failing to state a claim against BANA.
top_links.response_heading: 1. Mr. Caines' Request for Information Constituted a Proper QWR
top_links.response_content:
Defendant's first (half-hearted) argument for a shortcoming here is that the request for information sent by Mr. Caines did not constitute a proper qualified written request (QWR). This is not true.
[It] takes a "qualified written request" to trigger the loan servicer's duties under RESPA to acknowledge and respond. The statute defines a qualified written request as written correspondence (other than notices on a payment coupon or similar documents) from the borrower or her agent that requests information or states reasons for the borrower's belief that the account is in error. 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(B). To qualify, the written request must also include the name and account of the borrower or must enable the servicer to identify them. Id. Catalan v. GMAC Mortg. Corp., 629 F.3d 676, 680 (7th Cir. 2011).
Defendant quotes Catalan as holding: "Letters that 'merely dispute a debt or request information are not 'qualified written requests,' and do not trigger the obligations under section 2605.'"  (Def.'s Br. in Supp. of Mot. to Dismiss 5-6).  Although they note that citations were omitted, Defendant mistakenly attributed this comment to the Court.  (Id. at 6).  Actually, this statement was part of the mortgage company's brief!  The citation omitted was "GMAC Mortgage Br. 16."  Catalan, 629 F.3d at 686.  Defendant also omitted the first five words of the sentence that make it clear that the Court was not expressing its own opinion: "GMAC Mortgage argues that the . . . "  Id.
The Catalan Court's words actually reflect the opposite sentiment: "Any reasonably stated written request for account information can be a qualified written request."  Id. at 867.
RESPA does not require any magic language before a servicer must construe a written communication from a borrower as a qualified written request and respond accordingly. The language of the provision is broad and clear. To be a qualified written request, a written correspondence must reasonably identify the borrower and account and must "include a statement of the reasons for the belief of the borrower, to the extent applicable, that the account is in error or provides sufficient detail to the servicer regarding other information sought by the borrower." 12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(B) (emphasis added). * * * To the extent that a borrower is able to provide reasons for a belief that the account is in error, the borrower should provide them, but any request for information made with sufficient detail is enough under RESPA to be a qualified written request and thus to trigger the servicer's obligations to respond. Id.
Indeed, according to statute, the only other requirements for a communication to constitute a QWR is that it is "written correspondence, other than notice on a payment coupon or other payment medium supplied by the servicer, that includes, other otherwise enables the servicer to identify, the name and account of the borrower[.]"  12 U.S.C. § 2605(e)(1)(B).  "By GMAC Mortgage's argument [and that of Defendant here], a lender would have no obligation to respond to a borrower who expressed her belief that her account was in error but was unable to provide specific reasons for that belief, an untenable result under the language of the statute." Catalan, 629 F.3d at 686.
Mr. Caines' correspondence to Defendant fulfilled all of the statutory requirements necessary to constitute a QWR and thus to trigger the protections of RESPA.  Therefore, Count I of his Complaint should not be dismissed for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted.
2. Defendant Violated RESPA's Timeliness Requirements Anticipating that the Court might consider Mr. Caines' correspondence a proper QWR (which it clearly should), Defendant argued in the alternative that Mr. Caines' RESPA claim "still fails because [Defendant] timely responded to Plaintiff's request . . . . "  (Def.'s Br. in Supp. of Mot. to Dismiss 6).  Not so.  Defendant is mistaken in its construction of the law.
Even if Defendant received Mr. Caines' QWR on July 11th, 2011 (as asserted by the Defendant) and not July 5, 2011 (as asserted under the complaint), he was not provided with a response until more than 60 days later.  There are two points to be made here: (1) the calculation should include July 11, and thus Mr. Caines should have had a response to his QWR no later than October 3, 2011; and (2) Defendant's response was only dated (and possibly sent) on October 4 - Mr. Caines was not provided with the information he requested until he received the response several days later.

top_links.moving_heading: C. Count II: "Violation of the Indiana Home Loan Practices Act" Should be Dismissed for Failure to State a Claim
top_links.moving_content:
Count II fails to meet the federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and Rule 9(b), and therefore should be dismissed.  The Indiana Home Loan Practices Act prohibits persons from engaging in deceptive acts in connection with mortgage transactions.  I.C. § 24-9-3-7(c)(3). To establish a "deceptive act" Plaintiff must show that as part of a mortgage transaction BANA knowingly or intentionally: (1) made a material misrepresentation; or (2) concealed material information regarding the terms or conditions of the transaction.  I.C. § 24-9-2-7; Collins v. America's Servicing Company, 652 F.3d 711, 715 (7th Cir. 2011).  "Knowingly" means having actual knowledge at the time of the transaction.  I.C. § 24-9-2-7.
Merely reciting the elements of a cause of action without factual support, is not sufficient to state a claim.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 8.  To plead a cause of action demands more than an unadorned, "the-defendant-unlawfully-harmed-me accusation" or a "sheer possibility that a defendant has acted unlawfully." Iqbal, 129 S.Ct. at 1949 (citing Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555-56).  It "requires more than labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action will not do." Id. at 1954 (Rule 8 does not empower a defendant to plead the bare elements of a cause of action, affix the label "general allegation" and expect the complaint to survive a motion to dismiss), (citing Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555). Here, Plaintiff has failed to plead any facts to support his claim that BANA knowingly or intentionally made a material representation or concealed material information regarding the terms or conditions of his transaction, and instead merely concludes that BANA has done so.
Additionally, Plaintiff's claim under the IHLPA amounts to nothing more than allegations of misrepresentation or fraud; therefore, Plaintiff's claim must be pleaded with specificity. Fed. R. Civ. P. 9(b); Sears v. Likens, 912 F.2d 889, 893 (7th Cir. 1990) (ruling that officers failed to allege fraud with sufficient particularity where they neglected to "state in any detail what misrepresentations were made by the defendant, to whom these misrepresentations were made, when these misrepresentations were made, or how these misrepresentations furthered the alleged fraudulent scheme."); see also DiLeo v. Ernst & Young, 901 F.2d 624 (7th Cir.1990). In other words, Rule 9(b) requires the plaintiff to include "the 'who, what, when, and where' of the alleged fraud." Uni Quality, Inc. v. Infotronx, Inc., 974 F.2d 918, 923 (7th Cir.1992).  Here, Plaintiff fails to identify who made the alleged material misrepresentations, when, where, and about what.  Plaintiff merely states that "[t]hroughout [BANA]'s interactions with [Plaintiff], [BANA] engaged in one or more deceptive acts...with respect to [Plaintiff]'s home loan."  [See ¶ 60 of Plaintiff's Complaint].  Such a general allegation is utterly insufficient to inform the Court or BANA of what alleged acts constitute a knowing or intentional material misrepresentation under the Indiana Home Loan Practices Act. I.C. § 24-9-2-7.
Moreover, to the extent Plaintiff claims BANA engaged in a deceptive act in relation to the May 28, 2009, conditional loan modification offer, Plaintiff cannot establish that BANA knowingly or intentionally made a material misrepresentation or concealed information, because the plain language of the conditional loan modification offer sets forth all requirements to perform and the consequences of not performing. Collins supra, 652 F3d. at 715.  The conditional loan modification offer required that the agreement be returned, signed and notarized, as well as the bankruptcy stay be lifted prior to June 11, 2009, and payments be made on the first of each month.  [See Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  The conditional loan modification offer also expressly states that "[i]n the event you do not or cannot fulfill ALL of the terms and conditions of this letter no later than June 11, 2009, we will continue our collections actions without giving you additional notices or response periods."  [See Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].
Plaintiff's own rendition of the facts indicates he violated nearly every condition-he does not allege that he signed and returned the loan modification offer to BANA, and he states that he did not make the first payment by the deadline of July 1, 2009, but rather made his first payment nine months later on April 14, 2010.  [See ¶¶22 and 25 of Plaintiff's Complaint]. Plaintiff alleges however, that BANA received a payment on July 6, 2009, which even if this payment was made by Plaintiff, this late payment violated the terms.  Plaintiff also indicates there was no Bankruptcy related activity until October 2009, when the lifting of the stay needed to happen before June 11, 2009.  [See ¶¶ 20-25 of Plaintiff's Complaint and Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].
Any allegation that BANA's collection actions constitute deceptive acts fails, as the conditional loan modification agreement specifically allows BANA to continue with collection actions, including foreclosure, in the event Plaintiff "do[es] not or cannot fulfill ALL of the terms and conditions of the [conditional loan modification offer]". Collins, 652 F3d. at 715; See Baker v. America's Mortgage Servicing, Inc., 58 F.3d 321, 328 (7th Cir.1995) (assessment of late fees under a mortgage agreement does not violate a state's consumer fraud statute if they are assessed in accordance with the express terms of the contract).  Therefore, Count II of Plaintiff's claim should be dismissed.

top_links.moving_heading: D. Count III and V:  "Breach of Contract / Promissory Estoppel" and "Estoppel" Should be Dismissed for Failure to State a Claim
top_links.moving_content:
i. Breach of Contract
Count III of Plaintiff's Complaint fails to state a claim for breach of contract.  As a preliminary matter, it is well-established that a plaintiff cannot succeed on a breach of contract claim unless he demonstrates his own performance of the contract's requirements. See Hukic v. Aurora Loan Services, 588 F.3d 420, 433 (7th Cir.2009).  Here, Plaintiff failed to perform under the contract by his own admission, which is fatal to his claim.  The loan modification agreement states in ¶4 "[e]xcept as otherwise specifically provided in this Agreement, the Note and Security Instrument will remain unchanged, and the Borrower and Lender will be bound by, and comply with, all terms and provisions thereof, as amended by this Agreement."  [See Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  Like the loan modification agreement, ¶3(A) of the original Note provides that payments are due on the first of each month.  Also like the loan modification agreement, no grace period is provided; in fact ¶7(B) of the Note acknowledges that Plaintiff is in default if the payment is not made on the first of the month.  [See Exhibit B of Plaintiff's Complaint].
Here, the first payment was due on July 1, 2009, and by Plaintiff's own admission, the first payment was not made on time.  [See ¶¶22 and 25 of Plaintiff's Complaint].  At best, Plaintiff pleads BANA's records show a payment was received on July 6, 2009.2  [See ¶25 of Plaintiff's Complaint].  Even if Plaintiff alleged he made the first payment on July 6, 2009, which he does not, he is in default.  [See ¶¶ 3(A) and 7(D) of Exhibit B, and Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  Additionally, the conditional loan modification offer specifically required that the bankruptcy stay be lifted on or before June 11, 2009, for the agreement to take effect.  This did not occur until December 2009.  [See ¶22 of Plaintiff's Complaint].  The plain language of the conditional loan modification offer is clear, and Plaintiff failed to demonstrate he performed according to the terms of the conditional loan modification offer, thus Plaintiff's claim for breach of contract fails and should be dismissed. Hukic, 588 F.3d at 433.
ii. Promissory Estoppel
Counts III and V of Plaintiff's Complaint both assert a claim for promissory estoppel, however Plaintiff fails to state a claim.  Promissory estoppel requires:  (1) a promise by the promissor; (2) made with the expectation that the promisee will rely thereon; (3) which induces reasonable reliance by the promise; (4) of a definite and substantial nature; and (5) injustice can be avoided only by enforcement of the promise. Brown v. Branch, 758 N.E.2d 48, 52 (Ind. 2001).  "[T]he party asserting the doctrine carries a heavy burden establishing its applicability." Id. "In order to establish an estoppel to remove the case from the operation of the Statute of Frauds, the party must show [ ] that the other party's refusal to carry out the terms of the agreement has resulted not merely in a denial of the rights which the agreement was intended to confer, but the infliction of an unjust and unconscionable injury and loss." Id. at 52.  Here, the only representations alleged to have been made by BANA are expressly set forth in the original Mortgage and the written conditional loan modification offer.3  [See Exhibits A and C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  As indicated above, Plaintiff failed to comply with the express terms, thus Plaintiff's promissory estoppel claim also fails.  Additionally, Plaintiff does not establish, among other things, that justice would require the conditional loan modification offer to be enforced, or that Plaintiff suffered independent or substantial injury.
Assuming Plaintiff complied with all other conditions of the conditional loan modification agreement (i.e., returning the agreement, signed and notarized, and obtaining a relief from stay of the bankruptcy court4), Plaintiff still did not comply with the loan modification agreement because he did not make his payments on time.  [See ¶¶23 and 25 of Plaintiff's Complaint and Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  Any claim that continued acceptance of the partial payments gives rise to a claim for promissory estoppel also fails.  The original Mortgage and Note, which were incorporated into the loan modification agreement, allows BANA to accept late or partial payment without waiving any default or right to pursue remedies against Plaintiff.  [See ¶¶ 1 and 12 of Exhibit A and ¶ 7(D) of Exhibit B to Plaintiff's Complaint; and Exhibit C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  Plaintiff's continued late and insufficient payments do not cure his default under the original Note and Mortgage, thus BANA had the right to move forward with a collection action, and Plaintiff's Complaint should be dismissed. See Collins, supra, 652 F.3d at 715. [See ¶1 and 12 of Exhibit A and ¶ 7(D) of Exhibit B to Plaintiff's Complaint].
Finally, even if the Court determines Plaintiff has properly pleaded the other elements of promissory estoppel, Plaintiff fails to plead that reliance on BANA's alleged representations were to his detriment, thus Plaintiff's Complaint should be dismissed for failure to state a claim. Plaintiff has not, and cannot, allege that making the payments harmed him because Plaintiff was already obligated to make payments on this loan under the original Note and Mortgage.  [See Exhibits A and C to Plaintiff's Complaint].  The Indiana Supreme Court has held that "[i]f what the party gave up in reliance on an oral promise was no greater than what the party would have given up in any event, then the consideration is deemed insufficient to remove the oral promise from the operation of the Statute of Frauds." Brown v. Branch, 758 N.E.2d 48, 52 (Ind. 2001).

In its Motion to Dismiss, Defendant claims that Plaintiff, by his own admission, breached the conditional loan modification agreement and hence his Breach of Contract claim should be dismissed for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b). (Def.'s Br. in Supp. of Mot. to Dismiss 9) by making late payments. Mr. Caines did no such thing. Contrary to Defendants claims, Requirement (3) of the agreement does not state that Mr. Caines would be responsible for filing the motion for relief from stay, but that the bank should be able to obtain such relief.  From a practical standpoint, this is simply not the sort of motion filed by a debtor, since it is entirely for the benefit of the creditor.  Understandably, Mr. Caines did not interpret this provision of the agreement to mean that he would need to file such a motion, but rather that he would not oppose it. Similarly, requirement (4) was also contingent on Defendant obtaining title insurance. Defendant never contacted Mr. Caines regarding any liens on his property or for his assistance in acquiring said insurance. Defendant's contention that no loan modification agreement exists between the parties is contrary to principles of Judicial Estoppel and in direct contradiction with a court order issued by a Bankruptcy court judge upon a joint motion by the Parties. Furthermore, even if said court order or principles of Judicial Estoppel were ignored, Plaintiffs complied with the terms of the Conditional Modification Agreement and there is no reason why Defendants should not hold their end of the bargain.

top_links.moving_heading: E. Count IV:  "Breach of Good Faith and Fair Dealing" Should be Dismissed for Failure to State a Claim
top_links.moving_content: In Count IV, Plaintiff asserts that BANA's alleged failure to perform its contractual obligations under the "Mortgage Agreement"5 constitutes a breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing.  [See ¶71-74].  Plaintiff's claim fails because Indiana does not recognize a duty of good faith and fair dealing unless the contract relates to employment or insurance, or if a fiduciary relationship exists between the parties. First Federal Savings Bank of Indiana v. Key Markets, Inc., 559 N.E.2d 600, 604 (Ind. 1990).  Plaintiff does not, and could not plead any facts to establish any fiduciary relationship or special relationship to support such a claim because lenders owe no duty to borrowers, as a matter of law. Kreighbaum v. First National Bank & Trust, 776 N.E.2d 413, 419 (Ind. Ct. App. 2002).  The general rule in Indiana is that "the mere existence of a relationship between parties of bank and customer or depositor does not create a special relationship of trust and confidence." Huntington Mortg. Co. v. Debrota, 703 N.E.2d 160, 167 (Ind.Ct.App. 1998) (internal citations omitted).  Mortgages do not transform a traditional debtor-creditor relationship into a fiduciary relationship absent an intent by the parties to do so. Judd v. First Federal Sav. and Loan Ass'n, 710 F.2d 1237, 1241 (7th Cir. 1983). Plaintiff fails to state a claim for a breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing, thus Plaintiff's Complaint should be dismissed.
top_links.response_heading: D. Count IV: Breach of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
top_links.response_content:
Count IV of Mr. Caines' Complaint should not be dismissed for failure to state a claim. Defendant construes the requirements for the creation of a fiduciary relationship between a lender and borrower too narowly, and thus Mr. Caines should be permitted to pursue his case for a breach of good faith and fair dealing.
A fiduciary relationship does not exist between a lender and a borrower unless certain facts exist which establish a relationship of trust and confidence between the two. A confidential relationship exists whenever confidence is reposed by one party in another with resulting superiority and influence exercised by the other. Not only must there be confidence by one party in the other, but the party reposing the confidence must also be in a position of inequality, dependence, weakness, or lack of knowledge. Furthermore, it must be shown that the dominant party wrongfully abused this confidence by improperly influencing the weaker so as to obtain an unconscionable advantage. Whether such a relationship exists is essentially a question of fact.
